I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Air Quality Improvement in the Greater Beijing–
Tianjin–Hebei Region—Shandong Clean Heating and Cooling Project.1 The report also describes 
the proposed administration of technical assistance (TA) for the Air Quality Improvement in the 
Greater Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei Region—Shandong Clean Heating and Cooling Project to be 
provided by the Clean Energy Fund2 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, and 
if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the 
Board, approve the administration of the TA.  
 
2.  The proposed project is the fourth in a multiyear, multisector Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) support program for air quality improvement in the greater Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei (BTH) 
region. The first loan, which ADB approved in 2015, focused on policy reforms and strengthening 
regulatory capacity in Hebei Province.3 The second loan, approved in 2016, targeted better 
access to finance, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, to scale up investments in 
pollution reduction projects in the region.4 The third loan, approved in 2017, aimed to deploy 
advanced technologies to reduce air pollution from large emitters in the agriculture, energy, 
transport, and urban sectors.5 This proposed project will help Shandong Province shift to cleaner 
and more efficient heating and cooling by integrating various clean and renewable energy 
sources.6 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The greater BTH region is one of the most important economic regions in the PRC, 
generating about one-third of the country’s gross domestic product. However, it also has a dense 
population and a high concentration of energy-intensive and highly polluting industries, which 
result in widespread air pollution.7 Cities in the greater BTH region consistently top country 
rankings for the highest concentrations of particulate matter less than 2.5 micrometers in diameter 
(PM ) and other air pollutants. Exposure to high levels of PM  and other air pollutants is 
2.5 2.5
associated with health risks such as cardiovascular and respiratory disease, which contribute to 
more than 1 million premature deaths annually in the PRC. 
                                                
1  The original core Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei (BTH) region refers to Beijing and Tianjin municipalities and Hebei Province. 
Due to air pollution’s transboundary impact, in 2017, the government extended the core BTH region to its surrounding 
regions. The greater BTH region includes the original core BTH region and its surrounding regions of Henan, 
Liaoning, Shandong, and Shanxi provinces; and Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. 
2  Financing partners: the governments of Australia, Norway, Spain, Sweden, and the United Kingdom.

2 
4.  Shandong Province, as part of the greater BTH region, consistently experiences poor air 
quality that is attributable to an overreliance on coal as an energy source for heavy industry, 
electricity, and heating. The province is the PRC’s largest coal consumer, deriving 79.3% of its 
primary energy mix from coal. Whereas coal consumption in the PRC peaked in 2013 and started 
to decline, Shandong Province’s coal consumption increased substantially from 364.7 million tons 
in 2011 to 409.3 million tons in 2015.8 High levels of coal consumption, particularly by industry 
and urban and rural households, are the main contributors to poor air quality in the province. In 
2016, Jinan city had the highest concentration of PM attributable to coal use among 74 major 
2.5 
cities in the PRC, and it ranked ninth in the province for the poorest air quality. Jinan Municipal 
Bureau of Environmental Protection measured the annual average concentration of PM  in 2016
2.5  
at 73 micrograms per cubic meter (μg/m³), which is more than double the category II national 
ambient air quality standards.9 In Jinan, the annual concentration of PM specifically attributable 
2.5 
to coal use is 52 μg/m3, about 70% of total PM2.5 concentration levels. During winter, even higher 
levels—61 μg/m3 or 84%—of PM2.5 emissions are attributable to coal use.10 Emissions are 
exacerbated during winter by the burning of raw coal by households for heating. The health 
impacts of raw coal burning are more severe because of direct inhalation and the poor quality and 
high sulphuric content of the coal.  
 
5.  The Government of the PRC has made air quality improvement a national priority and 
views restructuring the energy mix as the key to realizing this objective. This is consistent with 
the climate change mitigation specified in the PRC’s intended nationally determined contributions. 
The PRC’s Thirteenth Five-Year Plan sets strict air quality measures and targets on PM ,sulfur 
2.5  
dioxide (SO ), nitrogen oxides (NO ), and volatile organic compounds nationally, and for the BTH 
2 x
region. In support of the government’s efforts on air quality improvement, ADB contributed, 
targeted, and coordinated financing of $1.3 billion (footnotes 3, 4, and 5) and the World Bank did 
the same for $1.0 billion. In 2017, the Ministry of Environmental Protection introduced the Work 
Program for Air Pollution Control in the BTH Region and Its Surrounding Areas.11 The program 
aims to implement strict pollution control measures in 28 cities, of which 7 are in Shandong 
Province. The program emphasizes the importance of reducing winter raw coal burning for 
heating supply in urban, semi-urban, and rural areas of the greater BTH region. 
 
6.  The Shandong Provincial Government has also committed to improving air quality. In 
2012, it published the Action Plan for Air Pollution Control for 2013–2020.12 The plan targeted 
reducing annual average PM2.5 concentration levels to 49 μg/m³ by 2020. To meet this target 
Shandong Province must reduce its coal consumption. Opportunities include exploiting the 
province’s  abundant geothermal  resources,  agricultural  waste,  and  waste  heat from  heavy 
industries. 
 
7.  The proposed project responds directly to the urgent national, provincial, and municipal 
government priorities to reduce coal consumption and improve air quality. This will be achieved

by introducing more efficient methods and advanced technology for heat production through 
replacing coal with cleaner sources of energy such as natural gas and renewable energy, and 
reducing raw coal burning among households.13 Soot pollution and other local pollutants such as 
PM ,SO , and NO  will be sharply reduced, especially for rural households, saving lives and 
2.5   2 x
improving the physical health of residents. The proposed project is well-aligned with the priorities 
of broadening the response to climate change and strengthening environmental sustainability in 
ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–2020.14 It will also support key strategic 
priorities  of  (i)  tackling  climate  change  by  using  advanced  technologies  to  accelerate  low 
greenhouse gas emissions development and ensure environmental sustainability, (ii) accelerating 
progress in gender equality through gender mainstreaming activities, and (iii) making cities more 
livable through air quality improvement resulting in safer and healthier urban environment for 
residents, as prescribed in ADB’s Strategy 2030.15  
 
8.  ADB’s value addition and lessons from previous operations. Air quality improvement 
requires coordinated interventions with different coverage and approaches. Unlike the first three 
projects in ADB’s multiyear, multisector support to the PRC for air quality improvement, this 
proposed project uses the project loan modality. Past projects used the financial intermediary 
modality because the subprojects they supported were spread among many sectors that required 
different business models and financing structures. The project loan modality is appropriate 
because the proposed project is narrowly focused on the heating and cooling industry in a 
concentrated geographic area, which can result in effective and efficient delivery of project 
outcomes and large pollution reductions in a locality. The proposed clean heating and cooling 
solutions will be a pilot in the PRC, with a large potential to be scaled up and duplicated in similar 
regions within and outside the country. ADB will organize technical knowledge exchange sessions 
during project implementation to strengthen the capacity of the implementing agencies and 
disseminate knowledge and lessons from this project to other developing member countries that 
face similar challenges in relation to cooling and heating. 
 
9.  Innovative features. The proposed project demonstrates advanced heating and cooling 
technologies with an innovative business model to deliver improved and efficient heating solutions 
to rural households in a cost-effective manner. The project utilizes government incentives to lower 
the upfront costs of heating solutions for rural households, while capitalizing on the technical 
expertise of the heating company to identify, manage, and deliver the most appropriate heating 
solutions to households and enabling the company to sustainably expand its service area to semi-
urban and rural areas around Jinan city. The project combines renewable energy technologies 
and waste heat recovered from industry and power plants and applies supply- and demand-side 
energy efficiency measures. This will reduce the energy and carbon intensity of heat production 
and refrigeration, and thereby reduce air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome

the greater BTH region improved (consistent with the Thirteenth Five-Year Plan).16 The project will

C.  Outputs 
 
11.  These subprojects contribute toward reducing emissions of pollutants and carbon dioxide 
in Shandong Province. The outcome will be achieved through the following outputs. 
 
12.  Output  1:  West  Jinan  Waste  Heat  Utilization  and  Clean  Energy  Subproject 
constructed. Jinan Thermal Power Co., Ltd. (JTPC) will install and commission a biomass-based 
combined heat and power plant, retrofit and expand the existing district heating network in west 
Jinan, construct and commission a geothermal heating system in an industrial park, and install 
and commission a clean heating system using heat pumps in residential areas that are not 
connected to a central heating network. 
 
13.  Output 2: Shanghe Coal-Free Clean Heating Demonstration Subproject constructed. 
Jinan Heating Group (JHG) will apply energy efficiency measures to 660,400 square meters (m2) 
of urban buildings and 30,000 rural households in Shanghe County, develop at least 98 deep-
well geothermal installations for district heating in urban and semi-urban areas of the county, 
deliver improved heating solutions to 80,000 households in rural Shanghe, and install and 
commission a 42-megawatt gas boiler and modular gas boilers in Shanghe. 
 
14.  Output  3:  East  Jinan  Low-Emission  Combined  District  Heating  and  Cooling 
Subproject constructed. JHG will retrofit and expand existing district heating network in east 
Jinan, construct and commission an efficient large-scale district cooling system in east Jinan, and 
develop thermal storage capacity to shift peak time household heating and cooling energy usage. 
 
15.  Output 4:  Clean heating awareness and the capacity to install and maintain clean 
heating and cooling systems strengthened. An awareness-raising program on the impact of 
environmental and health benefits of clean heating will be designed and implemented (at least 
40% of the participants are women).  A capacity development program will also be designed and 
supported to improve the knowledge of operation and maintenance of the new facilities. At least 
50 JHG and JTPC staff will be trained through short- and long-term training courses, of which at 
least 40% are women. And at least 700 women will be employed in new skilled and unskilled jobs 
generated by the project.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  The executing agency for the project is the Shandong Provincial Government. There are

for the East Jinan Low-Emission Combined District Heating and Cooling Subproject and the 
Shanghe Coal-Free Clean Heating Demonstration Subproject. Both JHG and JTPC are Jinan city 
state-owned enterprises and have previous experience in project operation and implementation, 
and management of projects financed by development partners. To effectively coordinate and 
supervise the project implementation, Shandong Provincial Government established a project 
management office in Jinan, led by Shandong Provincial Department of Finance, Shandong 
Provincial Department of Housing and Urban–Rural Development, and Shandong Provincial 
Development and Reform Commission, and involving Jinan Municipal Public Utilities Bureau,

III.  ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
23.  To strengthen project implementation capacity, ADB will provide an attached TA to (i) 
develop a road map for rural clean heating in northern PRC to provide integrated solutions 
combining advanced technologies, innovative financing, and appropriate business models; (ii) 
measure indoor air pollution reduction in the rural households before and after the installation 
of clean heating systems in the project areas, which will be the first time an ADB project has 
measured this  impact; (iii)  undertake  awareness  campaign  on  environmental  and  health 
benefits of clean heating; (iv) conduct a participant feedback survey in project areas to verify 
the benefits of clean heating including time saving for preparation of household energy for 
heating; and (v) support enhancing the knowledge and understanding of JHG and JTPC staff 
in advanced heating and cooling technologies.20 
 
24.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis to be 
provided by the Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility and 
administered by ADB (footnote 18). The government will provide counterpart support in the 
form of office accommodation, logistics, and facilities and remuneration of counterpart staff; 
studies, reports, data, other information and support needed for the TA; and other in-kind 
contributions.  
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
25.  Subproject 1: West Jinan Waste Heat Utilization and Clean Energy Subproject. This 
subproject will provide heat to urban residents and industrial and business customers. The 
technologies to be used on the project include the following: (i) JTPC will adopt large temperature 
difference waste heat exchange technology for transporting waste heat from the nearby power 
plants to the city. This technology has a higher heat transport capacity and lower heat losses over 
long distances than current networks. JTPC will use the waste heat to supply heating to about 80 
million m2 of buildings. (ii) JTPC needs to provide year-round heat supply to an industrial park 
located in west Jinan. A biomass-based combined heating and power plant using biomass 
briquette will supply heating to 1.54 million m2 of buildings and will generate electricity of 133 
gigawatt-hour per year. A feedstock assessment showed that the biomass plant will consume 
only 12% of the available agriculture waste. (iii) Jinan is endowed with geothermal resources. The

subproject will use deep-well reinjection technology to extract and exchange heat from the 
underground water, which will then be filtered and recharged to the same aquifer, and (iv) 
Distributed  gas-fired  boilers  will  be  used  to  supply  heat  to  a  few  newly  built  residential 
communities not covered by the heating network and where geothermal resources are not 
available. This subproject will enable Jinan to fully utilize waste heat in neighboring regions to 
form a waste-heat-dominated heating system with a supplementary distributed energy supply 
from biomass, geothermal energy, and natural gas. 
 
26.  Subproject 2: Shanghe Coal-Free Clean Heating Demonstration Subproject. This 
subproject covers the urban area of Shanghe County, the semi-urban area of 11 towns, and 
80,000 rural households where coal-fired stoves or coal-fired boilers are commonly used for 
space heating. The subproject will use geothermal energy as the main heat source to replace 
coal-fired heating. Other clean options, such as air-source heat pumps, will be selected as 
distributed heating sources where the pipeline network is not available. Gas-fired boilers will be 
installed as an auxiliary heat source. This subproject also plans to retrofit 660,400 m2 of urban 
buildings and 30,000 rural households to improve their energy efficiency. JHG will replace heavily 
polluting coal-fired stoves in 80,000 rural households by air-to-air heat pumps, air-to-water heat 
pumps, heat-storage radiators, carbon crystal plate radiators, and small household gas heaters.21 
This subproject will play an important role in, and have demonstration effect to, other counties in 
the northern PRC that face similar air quality issues caused by the winter heating.   
 
27.  Subproject 3: East Jinan Low-Emission Combined District Heating and Cooling 
Subproject. The central business district is located in east Jinan. The large heating and cooling 
demands of this area require a low-emission system that can supply both heat and cooling. For 
heating supply, east Jinan will have two options: (i) industrial waste heat supplied via a long-
distance pipeline to heat 6.2 million m2 buildings; and (ii) electrode boilers with heat storage that 
will use off-peak electricity at night, and then deliver hot water to the households in the daytime 
to heat an area of up to 700,000 m2. For district cooling, the subproject will adopt two technologies: 
(i) ice storage, which uses off-peak electricity during the night and stores the cooling energy in 
the form of ice that is melted to provide cooling during peak daytime hours and when the cooling 
demand is large enough; and (ii) a lithium bromide absorption chiller, driven by waste heat from 
the  power  plant,  to  deliver  cold  water  to  consumers  through  long-distance  pipelines.  The 
subproject aims to expand the area of waste heat supply, and at the same time use off-peak 
electricity to produce and store heating and cooling capacity to improve waste heat utilization and 
shift load from peak.  
 
28.  The technical due diligence confirmed the viability of the subprojects.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
29.  ADB estimated the economic internal rate of return of 43.0% for subproject 1, 33.2% for 
subproject 2, and 14.2% for subproject 3, with the environmental benefits well above the 6.0% 
economic cost of capital, making the project economically viable. Sensitivity testing indicated that 
the project is likely to remain sustainable even in the face of adverse economic impacts of various 
types. The economic analysis considered all the project-related costs, benefits from cost savings 
resulting from the use of alternative fuels and system efficiency improvements, and local and

10,000 households will use air-to-water heat pumps with CNY9,000 capital subsidy, 6,000 households will use heat-
storage radiators with CNY2,000 capital subsidy, 3,000 households will install carbon crystal plate radiators and 
1,000 households have access to gas pipeline will install small household gas heaters each with CNY2,000 capital 
subsidy from the government.

9 
global  environmental  benefits.  Global  environmental  benefits  from  carbon  dioxide  (CO ) 
2
abatement are valued at the 2016 global social cost of carbon of $36.3 per ton of CO , adjusted 
2
to 2018 price levels, and increased annually by 2%. Local environmental benefits from pollution 
emission  abatement  are  valued  by  estimating  the  cost  of  premature  mortality  (labor  loss) 
associated with the pollutants. The project will generate revenue from the sale of heat, electricity, 
steam, and cooling, and from the service connection fees collected from customers in the project 
areas. Financial analysis of the project indicated a financial internal rate of return of 8.40% for 
subproject 1, 6.71% for subproject 2, and 14.27% for subproject 3. The financial internal rates of 
return exceed the weighted average cost of capital of 2.02% for subproject 1, 1.67% for subproject 
2, and 1.84% for subproject 3. Sensitivity analysis showed the project is likely to remain financially 
viable under several potential adverse scenarios. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
30.  Financial  management  assessment.  ADB  conducted  the  financial  management 
assessment  following  ADB’s  Financial  Management  and  Analysis  of  Projects.22 The  result 
showed that JHG and JTPC have adequate financial management systems and procedures in 
place to meet ADB requirements. However, neither of them is familiar with ADB’s disbursement 
procedures, and this may delay the disbursements.23 To address the risk, ADB trained JHG and 
JTPC staff on disbursement during project preparation. ADB will provide more training programs 
during implementation. To mitigate the potential risks, financial leverage for JHG and JTPC should 
be controlled below 80% and both companies should set aside a mandatory reserve in a separate 
bank account equivalent to 1% of their ADB loan amount. JHG and JTPC will report the status of 
their reserve account in their regular monitoring report. ADB rated the financial management risk 
before mitigation moderate. 
 
31.  Procurement risk assessment. An assessment of the procurement capacity of JHG and 
JTPC showed they have skilled and experienced staff and well-established procedures and 
systems needed to manage procurement in a manner consistent with ADB’s requirements.24 Staff 
from JHG and JTPC received three training programs during project preparation. JHG and JTPC 
have experience in international competitive bidding for other projects financed by international 
development partners. They will also hire a qualified procurement consultant and a procurement 
agent to further strengthen their capacity to carry out ADB-related procurement. 
  
32.  Corruption prevention. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was 
explained  to  and  discussed  with  the  government,  JHG,  and  JTPC.  The  specific  policy 
requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM.25 ADB conducted integrity 
due diligence and did not identify any significant integrity risk.  
 
D.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
33.  Social benefits. The project will directly benefit 646,815 households or 1,988,011 people 
in the project area by providing clean heating and cooling.26 About 996,119 of the intended 
beneficiaries are women and about 2,091 of the households are headed by poor women. In 
addition, the project will supply clean heating to educational institutions, hospitals, and elderly 
care centers in the project area. There are about 35,860 children in 29 schools and kindergartens, 
                                                
22 ADB. 2005. Financial Management and Analysis of Projects. Manila. 
23 Financial Management Assessment Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
24 Project Procurement Risk Assessment Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).  
25 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
26 This is equivalent to 31.4% of the total population of Jinan city.

10 
about 440 patients and medical staff in 9 hospitals, and 729 elderly people and caregivers in 8 
elderly care centers. The shift from dirty coal-based heating and cooling to cleaner and safer 
technologies supported by the proposed project will (i) reduce cases of respiratory diseases 
through improved indoor and outdoor air quality; (ii) reduce carbon monoxide poisoning by 
providing safer heating and cooking fuel; (iii) provide a better medical environment by installing 
cleaner and more reliable heating services; (iv) improve living conditions through adequate and 
reliable heating services; (v) reduce fuel expenditure on heating and cooking by switching from 
individual household coal-based stoves; (vi) provide a more comfortable schooling environment 
during the winter by supplying cleaner and more reliable heating services; and (vii) increase 
income through job opportunities created during construction. These benefits will contribute 
directly to Sustainable Development Goals 3, 5, 7, and 11.27 The government will provide 
subsidies for the installation of clean heating systems under the project so that poor households 
 
will be able to choose and install the affordable clean energy heating system free of charge.
 
34.  Gender impact. Women in project sites have the main responsibility for the use and 
maintenance of coal stoves and are disproportionally affected by the resulting in-door air pollution. 
By switching the type of energy used in cooking and heating, the project will directly affect 
women’s health outcomes. The project will enable the sharp reduction in time spent by beneficiary 
women on unpaid household work related to the preparation of household energy for heating from 
a current average of 2.75 hours to less than 1 hour. This will allow more time for productive 
 
activities and self-development, which could lead to increased income.  
 
35.  The project is categorized as Effective Gender Mainstreaming. The project will (i) provide 
access to clean heating for about 2,091 households headed by poor women; (ii) improve the 
technical capacity of JHG and JTPC women staff on the operation and maintenance of the new 
facilities through training (at least 40% are women), (iii) ensure that women are employed in skilled 
and unskilled jobs generated by the project during construction and operation (at least 700 jobs 
for women); (iv) conduct campaigns to raise awareness of the environmental and health benefits 
of clean energy (at least 40% of the participants are women); (v) ensure the participation of 
women in consultations during project implementation (at least 40% of the participants are 
women);  and  (vi)  ensure  that  the  design  of  services  is  gender-sensitive.  The  project  will 
encourage JHG and JTPC to conduct a corporate gender analysis, which could lead to the drafting 
of a corporate gender action plan for JHG and JTPC during project implementation. The project 
will encourage JHG and JTPC to adopt an appropriate gender policy under its corporate social 
 
responsibility program with support from the TA. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
36.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.28 
 
37.  Environment (category A). ADB prepared an environmental impact assessment (EIA) 
and initial environmental examinations, including environmental management plans (EMPs) 
following national environmental regulations and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
Potential impacts during construction, including noise and dust emissions, construction waste and 
wastewater, community and public safety disturbances, and risks to occupational health and 
safety are mostly temporary, predictable, and reversible, and can be mitigated through the 
implementation of the EMPs. Potential adverse environmental impacts during operation include

11 
SO , particulate matter less than 10 micrometers in diameter, PM ,and NO  emissions; noise; 
2 2.5   x
solid and hazardous waste; wastewater discharge; risks of fire and well blowout; and risks to the 
community and occupational health and safety. JHG and JTPC will use low-NO  burners. Exhaust 
x
gas will be treated by selective noncatalytic reduction denitrification system, magnesium oxide 
desulfurization system, cyclone dust collector, and bag filter, and emitted through a 100-meter 
stack. The residual emissions will be offset by shutting down existing coal boilers and household 
stoves. Air quality modeling results show that the biomass-based combined heat and power plant 
component will have negligible impacts on air quality. The implementation of the EMPs and 
adherence to national regulations will mitigate other impacts. Sensitive ecosystems will not be 
affected.  JHG  and  JTPC  has  allocated  sufficient  budgets  in  the  EMPs  to  ensure  proper 
implementation  of  mitigation  and  monitoring  measures.  The  borrower  has  committed  to 
developing an emergency response plan in case of fire and well blowout. JHG and JTPC will 
establish an environmental and social safeguard unit under the project management office to 
implement the mitigation measures stated in the EIA, initial environmental examinations, and 
EMPs. The project management office will hire an independent loan implementation consultant 
to support in implementing the EMPs. JHG and JTPC obtained domestic EIA approvals from 
relevant environmental protection bureaus for all subprojects. 
 
38.  JHG and JTPC have carried out meaningful consultations with the public. JHG and JTPC 
have agreed on a set of environment-related loan covenants and have committed themselves to 
participating in training programs that will place a heavy emphasis on environmental safeguards. 
ADB disclosed the environment safeguard documents to the affected people and on the ADB 
website.29 Potential environmental complaints or disputes will be handled following the grievance 
redress  mechanism  established  for  the  project.  JHG  and  JTPC  will  submit  environmental 
monitoring reports to ADB semiannually during construction and annually during operation. The 
potential climate risks to the project components are high. ADB is conducting a climate risk 
assessment and will incorporate the findings of the assessment in the project design.  
 
39.  Involuntary resettlement (category C). The proposed project does not entail permanent 
or temporary physical or economic displacement as (i) heat exchange stations will use existing 
space in residential communities and buildings that is reserved for the construction of public 
facilities; (ii) heating and cooling pipelines will be laid underground within the existing right of way 
or along roadways; (iii) the biomass-based combined heat and power plant will be built on existing 
state-owned land that has already been acquired; (iv) geothermal and natural gas energy stations 
will be constructed in the existing vacant and reserved space inside government buildings, 
residential communities, and schools; and (v) clean heating facilities, such as heat pumps and 
distributed natural gas boilers, will be constructed on the vacant state-owned land or in existing 
buildings. ADB carried out due diligence for the associated facilities and for components where 
land acquisition had already been completed, and found no outstanding issues. 
 
40.  Indigenous peoples (category C). The project is not expected to have adverse impact 
on ethnic minorities as the project site is not near any ethnic minority towns or villages. 
 
41.   Environmental  benefits.  Compared  to  traditional  coal-based  heating  and  cooling 
systems, the facilities build by the project will emit about 90.0% less CO , 90.6% less NO , 96.0%

V.  ASSURANCES  
 
43.  The Government of the PRC and the Shandong Provincial Government have assured 
ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to all applicable ADB policies, including 
those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting 
services, and disbursement as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
44.  The Government of the PRC and the Shandong Provincial Government have agreed with 
ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the draft loan agreement and 
project agreement. 
 
VI.   RECOMMENDATION 
 
45.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
€350,000,000 to the People’s Republic of China for the Air Quality Improvement in the Greater 
Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei  Region—Shandong  Clean  Heating  and  Cooling  Project,  from  ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources, in regular terms, with interest to be determined in accordance with 
ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 25 years, 
including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board.
